unit_title: Magnetic Force on Moving Charges: Lorentz Force and Vector Cross Products
subject: AP Physics C: Electricity & Magnetism
expanded_description: This unit introduces the fundamental concepts of magnetic forces on moving charges, focusing on the Lorentz force law and the mathematical framework of vector cross products. Students will develop proficiency in three-dimensional vector analysis and apply these skills to predict charged particle motion in magnetic fields.
learning_objectives: Apply the Lorentz force law to calculate magnetic forces on moving charges
Master vector cross product operations in three dimensions
Predict charged particle trajectories in uniform magnetic fields
Analyze combined electric and magnetic force effects
Solve problems involving magnetic force direction using right-hand rules
Calculate work done by magnetic forces on moving charges
prerequisites: Understanding of vector mathematics and components
Proficiency with Newton's laws of motion
Knowledge of electric forces and fields
Familiarity with basic kinematics in two and three dimensions

core_concept.principle: Lorentz Force Law, Vector Cross Products, Right-Hand Rules, Charged Particle Motion, Magnetic Work Theorem
core_concept.explanation: Moving electric charges experience magnetic forces perpendicular to both their velocity and the magnetic field direction. This fundamental relationship, described by the Lorentz force law, requires three-dimensional vector analysis using cross products and leads to characteristic circular and helical motion patterns for charged particles in magnetic fields.

sections.section_title: 1. Lorentz Force Law and Vector Mathematics
sections.introduction: This section establishes the mathematical foundation for magnetic forces, introducing the Lorentz force law and developing proficiency with vector cross products in three-dimensional space.

key_concept.definition: Lorentz Force Law, Vector Cross Product, Right-Hand Rule, Force Direction, Perpendicular Relationships
key_concept.context: The magnetic force on a moving charge depends on the charge's velocity, the magnetic field strength, and their relative orientation. This relationship is mathematically described by the vector cross product, which produces a force perpendicular to both the velocity and field vectors. Understanding this three-dimensional interaction is crucial for predicting charged particle behavior in magnetic fields.

image.caption: Vector relationships in the Lorentz force law

classifications.value: Classification of magnetic force scenarios based on velocity-field orientation
characteristics: Perpendicular motion: maximum force and circular trajectories
Parallel motion: zero force and straight-line motion
Oblique motion: helical trajectories with constant speed
Crossed fields: electric and magnetic force balance
Non-uniform fields: focusing and mirror effects
classifications.behavior: Different velocity-field orientations produce distinct motion patterns. Perpendicular components cause circular motion while parallel components maintain straight-line motion. Combined effects create helical paths. Crossed fields can produce straight-line motion when forces balance. Time-varying fields accelerate charges, while non-uniform fields can trap particles.

examples.explanation: Charged particles with velocity perpendicular to uniform magnetic field execute uniform circular motion

image.caption: Charged particle executing circular motion in uniform magnetic field

examples.explanation: Crossed electric and magnetic fields that allow only particles with specific velocity to pass undeflected

image.caption: Crossed fields configuration for velocity selection

classifications.note: The magnetic force always acts perpendicular to the velocity vector, meaning it changes the direction of motion but does no work on the charged particle

principles.statement: Lorentz Force Law: F = q(v × B) where F is magnetic force, q is charge, v is velocity vector, B is magnetic field vector. The magnitude is F = |q|vBsinθ where θ is the angle between v and B. Vector Cross Product: A × B produces a vector perpendicular to both A and B with magnitude |A||B|sinθ. Right-Hand Rule: Point fingers in direction of first vector (v), curl toward second vector (B), thumb shows force direction for positive charge. Force Direction: Positive charges experience force according to right-hand rule. Negative charges experience opposite force. Perpendicular Nature: Magnetic force is always perpendicular to both velocity and field, resulting in zero work done. Component Analysis: For perpendicular components, F_max = |q|v⊥B. For parallel components, F = 0. Vector Components: In Cartesian coordinates, v × B = (v_yB_z - v_zB_y)i + (v_zB_x - v_xB_z)j + (v_xB_y - v_yB_x)k.
principles.application: Calculate magnetic force magnitude and direction for given charge, velocity, and field. Determine particle acceleration from magnetic force. Analyze force components in three dimensions. Predict initial force direction using right-hand rules. Solve for unknown quantities in magnetic force equations.
principles.example: Proton moving east in magnetic field pointing north experiences upward force. Electron with same parameters experiences downward force. Particle with velocity parallel to field experiences zero force.
principles.analogy: The magnetic force relationship is like a 'mechanical gear system'. The 'velocity vector' is like the 'rotation of the first gear', the 'magnetic field' is like the 'orientation of the second gear', and the resulting 'force' is like the 'output rotation' that's perpendicular to both input rotations. Just as gears must mesh at right angles to transfer motion efficiently, the magnetic force acts at right angles to both the motion and the field. The 'right-hand rule' is like the 'gear engagement rule' that determines the direction of the output rotation.

worked_examples.title: Basic Lorentz Force Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A proton (q = +1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) moves with velocity v = (3.0 × 10⁶ i + 4.0 × 10⁶ j) m/s through a magnetic field B = (0.50 k) T. Find the magnetic force on the proton.

step_by_step.explanation: F = q(v × B) = q[(v_yB_z - v_zB_y)i + (v_zB_x - v_xB_z)j + (v_xB_y - v_yB_x)k]
v in xy-plane, B in +z direction, right-hand rule gives force in xy-plane perpendicular to v

worked_examples.final_answer: F = (3.2 × 10⁻¹³ i - 2.4 × 10⁻¹³ j) N, magnitude = 4.0 × 10⁻¹³ N, direction in xy-plane

worked_examples.title: Right-Hand Rule Application
worked_examples.problem: An electron enters a region with uniform magnetic field pointing into the page with initial velocity to the right. Determine the direction of the initial magnetic force and describe the resulting motion.

step_by_step.step: Apply right-hand rule for positive charge
step_by_step.explanation: For positive charge: point fingers right (v), curl into page (B), thumb points upward
Electron experiences force opposite to right-hand rule result, so force is downward
Force is perpendicular to velocity, causing circular motion. For downward initial force, electron will curve downward initially
Looking from above: electron will curve clockwise (opposite to positive charge)

worked_examples.final_answer: Initial magnetic force is downward. Electron will execute clockwise circular motion in the plane of the page.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Right-hand rule for negative charges and motion prediction

worked_examples.title: Force Magnitude with Angular Dependence
worked_examples.problem: A charged particle with q = 2.0 μC moves at 5.0 × 10⁴ m/s through a 0.80 T magnetic field. Calculate the magnetic force when the angle between velocity and field is: (a) 90°, (b) 30°, (c) 0°

step_by_step.explanation: Maximum force at 90°, half maximum at 30°, zero force when parallel to field

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) 0.080 N, (b) 0.040 N, (c) 0 N. Demonstrates the sinθ dependence of magnetic force.

sections.section_title: 2. Charged Particle Motion in Magnetic Fields
sections.introduction: This section explores the characteristic motion patterns of charged particles in magnetic fields, including circular motion, helical paths, and applications like mass spectrometers and cyclotrons.

key_concept.definition: Circular Motion, Helical Trajectories, Gyroradius, Cyclotron Frequency, Magnetic Confinement
key_concept.context: When charged particles move through uniform magnetic fields, they experience constant-magnitude forces perpendicular to their motion, resulting in characteristic curved trajectories. The perpendicular velocity component causes circular motion, while any parallel component produces helical paths. These motion patterns form the basis for numerous practical applications in particle physics and engineering.

image.caption: Charged particle trajectories in magnetic fields

classifications.value: Classification of charged particle trajectories based on initial conditions
characteristics: Pure circular motion: velocity entirely perpendicular to B-field
Helical motion: velocity has both perpendicular and parallel components
Straight-line motion: velocity parallel to B-field
Complex trajectories: in non-uniform or time-varying fields
Magnetic mirroring: in converging field lines
Drift motions: in crossed electric and magnetic fields
classifications.behavior: Different initial conditions produce distinct motion patterns. Circular motion has constant radius and period. Helical motion combines circular motion with constant drift. Straight-line motion continues unaffected. Complex trajectories occur in practical field configurations. Magnetic mirroring reflects particles in converging fields. Crossed fields cause drift perpendicular to both fields.

examples.explanation: Charged particles executing circular motion with constant cyclotron frequency

image.caption: Circular motion of charged particle in uniform magnetic field

examples.explanation: Particle reflection in regions of increasing magnetic field strength

image.caption: Particle reflection in converging magnetic field

classifications.note: The magnetic force cannot change the speed or kinetic energy of a charged particle, only its direction of motion

principles.statement: Circular Motion: For v⊥B, magnetic force provides centripetal acceleration: |q|vB = mv²/r. Gyroradius: r = mv/(|q|B) - radius of circular path. Cyclotron Frequency: f = |q|B/(2πm) - frequency of revolution. Angular Frequency: ω = |q|B/m. Helical Motion: For v with both ⊥ and ∥ components, superposition of circular motion and constant drift. Pitch: distance between helix turns = v∥T = 2πmv∥/(|q|B). Magnetic Work Theorem: dW = F·ds = 0 since F⊥v, so magnetic fields do no work. Energy Conservation: Kinetic energy remains constant in pure magnetic fields. Speed Conservation: |v| remains constant, only direction changes. Mass Spectrometry: r ∝ m for fixed q, v, B - basis for mass separation. Velocity Selector: E = vB for straight-line motion in crossed fields.
principles.application: Calculate radius and period of circular motion. Determine helical motion parameters. Analyze particle trajectories in magnetic fields. Solve for unknown masses or charges from motion observations. Design magnetic confinement systems. Analyze mass spectrometer operation.
principles.example: Proton in 1 T field with 10⁶ m/s perpendicular velocity has r ≈ 0.01 m and f ≈ 15 MHz. Electron with same parameters has much smaller r and higher f.
principles.analogy: Charged particle motion in magnetic fields is like a 'ball on a string' being swung in circles. The 'magnetic force' acts like the 'tension in the string' - always perpendicular to the motion, constantly pulling the particle into a curved path. The 'gyroradius' is like the 'length of the string' - longer for heavier particles (larger m) or faster motion (larger v), but shorter for stronger 'pull' (larger B). The 'cyclotron frequency' is like the 'swinging rate' - independent of how fast you're swinging, just depends on the 'string properties'. Helical motion is like 'swinging the ball while walking forward' - circular motion combined with linear drift.

image.caption: Circular and helical motion parameters in magnetic fields

worked_examples.title: Circular Motion Parameters
worked_examples.problem: An electron (m = 9.11 × 10⁻³¹ kg, q = -1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) moves perpendicular to a 0.010 T magnetic field with speed 2.0 × 10⁶ m/s. Find the radius, period, and frequency of its circular motion.

step_by_step.explanation: r = mv/(|q|B) - use magnitude of charge for radius calculation

worked_examples.final_answer: Radius = 1.14 mm, Frequency = 280 MHz, Period = 3.57 ns. Electron executes very rapid circular motion with small radius.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Circular motion parameters in magnetic field

worked_examples.title: Helical Motion Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A proton (m = 1.67 × 10⁻²⁷ kg, q = +1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) enters a 0.50 T magnetic field with velocity v = (4.0 × 10⁶ i + 3.0 × 10⁶ k) m/s. Describe its motion and find the helix radius and pitch.

step_by_step.explanation: Assume B = B j (in y-direction). v_x = 4.0 × 10⁶ m/s, v_z = 3.0 × 10⁶ m/s, v_y = 0
v⊥ = √(v_x² + v_z²) = √(16 + 9)×10⁶ = 5.0 × 10⁶ m/s (since B is in y-direction, both x and z components are perpendicular)
v∥ = v_y = 0 m/s (since B is in y-direction and v has no y-component)
Problem states v = (4.0×10⁶ i + 3.0×10⁶ k) but doesn't specify B direction. Assume B = B k for this to make sense as helical motion.
Let B = (0.50 k) T. Then v∥ = v_z = 3.0 × 10⁶ m/s, v⊥ = v_x = 4.0 × 10⁶ m/s

worked_examples.final_answer: Proton executes helical motion with radius 8.35 cm and pitch 39.3 cm. Circular motion in xy-plane with drift along z-axis.

image.caption: Proton helical trajectory in magnetic field

worked_examples.title: Mass Spectrometer Application
worked_examples.problem: In a mass spectrometer, singly ionized atoms (q = +e) are accelerated through 1000 V, then enter a 0.200 T magnetic field perpendicularly. If the radius of curvature is measured as 8.50 cm, determine the atomic mass.

step_by_step.explanation: Kinetic energy from acceleration: ½mv² = qV = eV

worked_examples.final_answer: Atomic mass = 13.93 u. This identifies the atoms as nitrogen-14 (most common isotope).

common_misconceptions: Thinking magnetic forces can do work on charged particles
Believing magnetic fields can change particle speed
Confusing right-hand rule directions for negative charges
Assuming all magnetic forces cause circular motion
Thinking parallel velocity components affect circular motion radius
Believing magnetic force depends on particle mass
Confusing electric and magnetic force behaviors
real_world_applications: Cathode ray tubes and old TV displays
Space weather and radiation belt modeling
summary: This unit has established the fundamental principles of magnetic forces on moving charges through the Lorentz force law and vector cross product mathematics. Students have developed proficiency in calculating magnetic forces, predicting charged particle trajectories, and understanding characteristic motion patterns including circular and helical paths. The applications to practical devices like mass spectrometers and the fundamental limitation of magnetic forces doing no work provide a comprehensive foundation for advanced study of electromagnetism.
